STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 15, 2024
Lauryn Ritchie
Let's Talk About it Girl's Home III
615 W. Lovell,
Kalamazoo, MI, 49007
Re: License #: CI390403045
Investigation #: 2024SIC0001334
Dear Ms. Ritchie:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis
Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024SIC0001334
Special Investigation Intake Date: April 11, 2024
License #: CI390403045
Licensee Group Organization: Let's Talk About It CMH Services, PLLC
Licensee Designee: Tonya Moore
Chief Administrator: Lauryn Ritchie
Agency Name: Let's Talk About it Girl's Home III
Agency Address: 615 W. Lovell
Kalamazoo, MI 49007
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/17/2024
Capacity: 14
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
4/12/2024 9:30 AM Onsite Inspection Unannounced Visit; Special
Investigation Initiation; Interview
4/12/2024 10:14 AM Phone Interview
4/12/2024 11:20 AM Phone Interview
4/12/2024 11:44 AM Phone Interview
4/12/2024 3:06 PM Text Other
4/12/2024 3:10 PM Email Other
4/15/2024 4:46 PM Email Documentation received or sent
4/17/2024 9:33 AM Email Other
4/19/2024 7:15 AM Onsite Inspection Announced Visit; Documentation
received or sent; Interview
4/19/2024 12:19 PM Email Other
1

4/22/2024 1:16 PM Email Documentation received or sent
4/26/2024 8:19 AM Phone Interview
4/30/2024 10:00 AM Phone Interview
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff do not complete bed checks every 12-15 minutes. Staff sleep
in chairs in corners where cameras won't see them.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was anonymous.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone on 4/12/24.
Administrator 1 reported after they had a similar investigation at
one of their other facilities, they called all the staff in from this
facility and had a staff meeting about the supervision policy, bed
checks, not sleeping on shift, etc. Administrator 1 reported no
concerns have been brought to her attention regarding staff
sleeping on shift or not completing bed checks as required.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 4/12/24. CA reported no concerns have been brought
to her attention regarding staff sleeping on shift or not completing
bed checks as required. CA reported Staff 2 had never talked to
her about staff sleeping on shift. CA reported Staff 1 and Staff 2
were both terminated this week, so they anticipated a complaint
was going to be called in about something since it has been a
trend after employee terminations.
Licensee Designee (LD) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 4/19/24. LD reported completing bed checks as
required and not sleeping on shift have been topics discussed
during staff meetings over the last couple months due to the
investigation at their other facility. LD reported no concerns have
been brought to her attention regarding Staff 3, Staff 5 or Staff 6
sleeping on shift. LD reported Staff 1 never texted her about his
concerns regarding Staff 3 sleeping on shift. LD reported the only
complaint she received about someone sleeping on shift was a
few months ago regarding Staff 1, which he received a write-up
2

for. LD reported the only chair off camera is the one in the living
room on the main level located right under the camera. After
watching video footage from Staff 6’s shift between 3/16/24-
3/17/24, LD reported the chair will be removed to ensure no staff
sit there moving forward. LD noted this due to viewing Staff 6
sitting in the chair and not moving around during the shift, but LD
not being able to discern whether he was sleeping or not.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/19/24.
Youth A reported she has never seen any staff sleeping on shift.
She reported she knows staff do bed checks because she wakes
up when they’re being done.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/19/24.
Youth B reported she has never seen any third shift staff sleeping
on shift. She reported she saw Staff 4 sleeping on shift a couple
times when Staff 4 first started, but it’s been a while. Youth B
reported Staff 4 had two jobs, so if it wasn’t busy, she would nod
her head like she was dozing off, but she would wake right back
up. Youth B reported she has never complained to anyone about
staff sleeping on shift, so she’s not sure why anyone would say
that. Youth B reported she’s never had any concerns about third
shift staff.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 4/12/24. Staff 1 reported
he no longer works at the facility as he was terminated on 4/11/24.
Staff 1 reported he knows Staff 3 is sleeping on shift because two
weeks ago he came in on first shift and saw her sleeping in a chair
in the second-floor hallway. Staff 1 reported when he went
upstairs, Staff 3 was asleep, so he tapped her on the shoulder and
Staff 3 said, “you just woke me up”. Staff 1 reported Staff 4 told
him she has seen Staff 3 sleeping on shift multiple times as well.
Staff 1 reported he has never seen any other staff sleeping on
shift, but Staff 6 has told him she’s upset because she works third
shift and Staff 5 has been sleeping downstairs when they work
together. Staff 1 stated he never reported this concern to anyone.
When asked why he is bringing it up now, he said, “no reason”.
Staff 1 then reported he told LD about his concern in a text
message and stated he would send a screenshot as verification. It
should be noted, after multiple requests, a screenshot was never
received.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 4/12/24. Staff 2 reported
she no longer works at the facility because she retired on 4/8/24.
Staff 2 reported when she has come in to work for first shift, she
has witnessed Staff 3 just waking up. Staff 2 reported last month,
3

Staff 3 told her she had dozed off and was just waking up because
she had worked a double shift. Staff 2 reported all the youth were
upset because Staff 3 didn’t wake them up timely. Staff 2 reported
Staff 5 is covered with a blanket when she comes in but hasn’t
witnessed him sleeping. Staff 2 reported she told CA all this
information about 3 weeks ago and CA responded they know who
is sleeping or not sleeping because they watch the cameras.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/19/24.
Staff 3 reported she typically works third shift and normally works
with Staff 8 but has also worked with Staff 5 and Staff 6. Staff 3
admitted she has dozed off before because third shift can be
brutal. Staff 3 reported she has closed her eyes but could not
recall if she’s slept during a shift. Staff 3 reported it’s possible she
dozed off long enough to miss a bed check, but she was not
positive. Staff 3 reported it’s been better since she and Staff 8
began switching off every 3 hours who was doing bed checks and
who was doing other tasks. Staff 3 reported she doesn’t
remember a time when Staff 1, Staff 2 or Staff 4 saw her sleeping
or woke her up when they came in for first shift. Staff 3 reported
she worked a double shift in March 2024, but couldn’t remember if
she slept during the shift. Staff 3 admitted she might not be perfect
at completing bed checks as required, but she tries to stay close
to the timeframes as possible. Staff 3 reported she has never
seen Staff 5 or Staff 6 sleeping on shift.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 4/12/24. Staff 4 reported
she no longer works at the facility because she quit on 3/22/24
due to not feeling safe with the youth there anymore. Staff 4
reported she has come in on first shift multiple times between
November 2023-January 2024 and has seen Staff 3, Staff 5 and
Staff 6 sleeping on different occasions. Staff 4 reported she didn’t
notice anyone sleeping on shift while the special investigation
regarding similar concerns was occurring at the other facility. Staff
4 reported Staff 3 told her Administrator 1 was calling her and
texting her on shift making sure she was doing bed checks
because Administrator 1 was watching the cameras. Staff 4
reported Staff 3 began sleeping on shift again in March 2024. Staff
4 reported Staff 3, Staff 5 and Staff 6 know where to sit and sleep
so the cameras cannot see them. Staff 4 reported she assumes
Staff 3, Staff 5 and Staff 6 are not completing bed checks as
required since they’ve been sleeping on shift. Staff 4 reported she
never spoke to CA, LD, Administrator 1, or Administrator 2 about
her concerns because Staff 3 is Administrator 1’s daughter.
4

Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 4/26/24. Staff 5 reported
until 3 weeks ago, he wasn’t allowed to complete bed checks
because he was a male staff. Staff 5 reported when he worked, he
would make sure the house was clean, do chores, prepare meals
for the next day, and complete the communication log. Staff 5
reported he typically gets his chores done first, and then sits in the
living room the remainder of the shift. Staff 5 reported he sits in
the chair under the camera in the living room because the plug by
the chair is the only one that works for his laptop charging box.
Staff 5 reported he also likes sitting there because it’s directly in
front of the TV, which he watches during his shift. Staff 5 reported
he has a blanket over him while he’s sitting in the chair because
the house gets cold at night, even if he’s wearing warm clothing.
Staff 5 reported he is not a phone person, which is why he’s not
on his phone and it's typically sitting next to him while he watches
TV. Staff 5 reported when he first started working third shift at the
facility in August 2023, he would fall asleep or doze off while
working, but he got used to working third shift and it hasn’t been a
problem in a while. Staff 5 reported he knows he’s not supposed
to sleep on shift, and he’s gotten into a good routine, so he hasn’t
had any issues falling asleep or dozing off on shift. Staff 5
reported he hasn’t had any concerns about Staff 3 or Staff 6
sleeping on shift.
Staff 6 was interviewed via phone on 4/30/24. Staff 6 reported
she has never fallen asleep on shift and has never seen anyone
else sleeping on shift. Staff 6 reported she never talked to Staff 1
about concerns regarding Staff 5 sleeping on shift. Staff 6
reported staff always try to keep each other awake by talking to
each other or being on their phones. Staff 6 reported her phone
alarms are loud, so she never misses a bed check. Staff 6
reported last year, she was having trouble completing bed checks
every 15 minutes or less, but this year she hasn’t had any trouble
completing bed checks as required.
Staff 7 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/19/24.
Staff 7 reported she works first shift, but she has worked third shift
a couple times. Staff 7 reported she has never seen Staff 3, Staff
5, or Staff 6 sleeping on shift, and she has never had to wake
them up when she has come in for first shift. Staff 7 reported she
has never had concerns about staff not completed bed checks.
Staff 8 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/19/24.
Staff 8 reported she works third shift and normally works with Staff
3. Staff 8 reported recently she and Staff 3 began switching off
every 3 hours who is upstairs doing bed checks and who is on the
5

main level doing other tasks. Staff 8 reported prior to that, she and
Staff 3 would switch off different days who was upstairs doing bed
checks for an entire shift and who was completing other tasks on
the main level. Staff 8 reported since they are not on the same
floor together, she doesn’t know if Staff 3 has ever slept on shift,
but she has never seen her sleeping. Staff 8 reported she has
never seen Staff 5 or Staff 7 sleeping on shift either. Staff 8
reported when she is working, she completes bed checks
consistently between 10–15 minute intervals. Staff 8 reported she
has never had any concerns about any staff she’s worked with not
completing bed checks as required.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from the following dates and timeframes was
reviewed. None of the videos reviewed showed Staff 1, Staff 2 or
Staff 4 waking up Staff 3, Staff 5, or Staff 6 upon arriving for their
shift.
• 3/13/24 at 10:00pm until 3/14/24 at 8:00am.
o Administrator 2 completed 8 bed checks from
10:30pm until 11:54pm, all of which were 15 minutes
or less.
o Staff 3 completed 14 bed checks from 12:05am-7:00
am, and 12 of those exceeded 15 minutes. The
longest timeframes without bed checks being
completed were 2:30am-3:30am and 4:39am-
6:06am.
o From approximately 2:07am-2:23 am, Staff 3’s
phone fell into her lap, her head fell forward, and it
appears she was asleep. There are 4 other periods
of time between 2:30am-7:00am where Staff 3 does
not move, and it appeared she was asleep.
• 3/15/24 at 10:00pm until 3/16/24 at 8:00am.
o Staff 6 completed 34 bed checks from 10:00pm-
7:49am, and 12 of those exceeded 15 minutes. The
longest timeframes without a bed check being
completed were from 2:23am-3:38am and 7:03am-
7:49am.
o At 2:23 am, Staff 6 was sitting in a chair, put her
phone down, covered up with a blanket and laid her
head back. She appeared to be asleep until 2:45am
when she picked up her phone again. At 3:30am,
she put her phone down and again laid her head
back. She appeared to be asleep until completing a
bed check at 3:38am. At 7:03am, she again put her
phone down, curled up and laid her head back. She
appeared to be asleep until approximately 7:49am.
6

• 3/16/24 at 10:30pm until 3/17/24 at 8:00am.
o Staff 3 completed 17 bed checks between 10:34pm-
7:47am, and all of them exceeded 15 minutes. The
longest timeframes without bed checks being
completed were 2:38am-3:43am, 3:34am-4:33am,
4:34am-5:59am and 6:00am-7:47am. Staff 3
appeared to be sleeping from 2:38am-3:27am and
4:33am-5:16am.
o Staff 5 is viewed to be on the main level of the home
from 12:57am-8:02am. He is seen seated in a chair
in the living room, covered up with a blanket, and the
TV is on. However, the chair is under the view of the
camera, so only his feet and legs could be seen. At
times his phone can be seen in his hand in his lap,
but most of the time, it’s on the table next to the
chair. Although he doesn’t get up or move much, it is
unknown if he is sleeping since his face cannot be
seen.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Staff schedules were reviewed. Staff 3 worked a double
shift from 3/13/24-3/14/24.
• Bed check logs for 3/4/24-3/31/24 were reviewed.
o Staff 3, Staff 6, and Staff 8 documented bed
checks exceeding 15 minutes.
o From 3/8/24-3/9/24, Staff 3 and Staff 8 did not
document any bed checks after 4:36am.
o From 3/13/24-3/14/24, Staff 3 did not document
any bed checks after 4:45am.
o From 3/16/24-3/17/24, 3/20/24-3/21/24, 3/26/24-
3/27/24, 3/27/24-3/28/24, 3/30/24-3/31/24, and
3/31/24-4/1/24, Staff 3 documented all her
checks at 15-minute increments exactly, rather
than at variable intervals.
o From 3/28/24-3/29/24, 3/29/24-3/30/24, and
3/31/24-4/1/24, Staff 6 documented all her
checks at 15-minute increments exactly, rather
than at variable intervals.
• Supervision Policy (rev. 3/6/24) states during sleeping
hours, employees should complete eyes on, variable
interval checks, not to exceed 15 minutes between
checks. Employees are responsible for documenting the
completion of their bedroom checks. Under no
7

circumstances should employees be asleep during their
shift.
• Staff 3’s employee file was reviewed. Staff 3 was
terminated on 10/17/22 for a reason unrelated to this
investigation and was rehired in August 2023. Staff 3
was trained on the Supervision policy and bed checks
during orientation on 8/17/23, as well as during staff
meetings on 2/12/24, 3/11/24, and 4/8/24. Staff 3 signed
off on her understanding of the supervision policy on
4/8/24.
• Staff 5 does not have any disciplinary actions in his
employee file. Staff 5 was trained on the Supervision
policy and bed checks during orientation on 8/23/24 and
8/24/24, as well as during staff meetings on 2/12/24 and
4/8/24. Staff 5 signed off on his understanding of the
supervision policy on 4/8/24.
• Staff 6 does not have any disciplinary actions in her
employee file. Staff 6 was trained on the Supervision
policy and bed checks during orientation on 11/7/24 and
11/8/24, as well as during staff meetings on 2/12/24,
3/11/24 and 4/8/24.
• Staff 8 does not have any disciplinary actions in her
employee file. Staff 8 was trained on the Supervision
policy and bed checks during orientation on 8/21/23 and
8/22/23 as well as during staff meetings on 2/12/24,
3/11/24 and 4/8/24. Staff 8 signed off on her
understanding of the supervision policy on 4/8/24.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per interviews
conducted, video footage reviewed, and documents reviewed,
Staff 3, Staff 6, and Staff 8 did not complete bed checks as
required. In addition, Staff 3 and Staff 6 were seen sleeping on
shift.
Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was offered to the agency that staff must
ensure they are completing bed checks at variable intervals.
There were multiple checks documented on bed logs that were 12
or 15 minutes exactly for most of the shift.
8

Consultation
Consultation was offered to the facility on 4/19/24 regarding
moving the living room chair out from underneath the camera’s
view to ensure staff can be seen on camera.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & ACT 116 - 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination
Section of conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
Description department, bureau of fire services, or local authorities;
records; reports report; forms; confidentiality; disclosure of
information; availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department; failure of
licensee to cooperation with investigation, inspection, or
examination.
(1) The department may investigate, inspect, and examine
conditions of a childcare organization and may investigate
and examine the books and records of the licensee. The
licensee shall cooperate with the department’s
investigation, inspection, and examination by doing all of
the following:
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the
department, and encouraging witnesses, such as
staff and household members, to provide accurate
and truthful information to the department.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Documentation is falsified to reflect the observation checks are
occurring as required.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 4/12/24. Staff 2 reported
she has seen blank observation log sheets when she came in for
first shift, so she knows third shift staff have not completed them
as required. She reported she noticed it about 2-3 months ago.
She was unable to provide the name of a staff who wasn’t
completing the logs.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/19/24.
Staff 3 reported she fills out the bed check forms consistently.
Staff 3 reported it is possible there could have been a situation
she documented a time she didn’t completed a bed check but
didn’t remember a specific instance and could not say definitively
one way or the other. Staff 3 reported she has come into work and
seen other staff have not filled out the observation logs for a night
she didn’t work but could not recall a timeframe for when it
occurred or which staff worked the night it occurred.
9

Staff 6 was interviewed via phone on 4/30/24. Staff 6 reported
she always writes the times on the observation logs as she does
the bed checks. Staff 6 reported she has never documented times
on the logs when she didn’t complete a bed check.
Staff 10 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/19/24.
Staff 10 reported she normally works third shift with Staff 3. Staff
10 reported she has never falsified any bed checks. Staff 10
reported she does not know if any other staff have falsified them
because they’re not normally working on the same floor of the
house at the same time.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from the following dates and timeframes was
reviewed:
• From 3/13/24 at 10:00pm until 3/14/24 at 8:00am,
Administrator 2 completed 8 bed checks between
10:30pm-11:54pm and Staff 3 completed 14 bed checks
between 12:05am-7:00am.
• From 3/15/24 at 10:00pm until 3/16/24 at 8:00am, Staff
6 completed 34 bed checks.
• From 3/16/24 at 10:30pm until 3/17/24 at 8:00am, Staff
3 completed 17 bed checks.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Bed check logs for 3/4/24-3/31/24 were reviewed and
compared to video footage reviewed.
o For the overnight shift from 3/13/24-3/14/14, Staff
3 documented 21 bed checks on the observation
logs, but only completed 14 bed checks
according to video footage. In addition, only 2
checks on the logs matched the times she
completed them based on video footage
reviewed. Staff 3 did not document any bed
checks after 4:45am despite video footage
showing she completed 3 additional checks.
o For the overnight shift from 3/15/24-3/16/24, Staff
6 documented 37 bed checks on the observation
logs, but she only completed 34 bed checks
according to video footage. In addition, out of the
37 she documented, only 6 checks were
completed at the same time or within a minute of
the time she wrote on the logs.
o For the overnight shift from 3/16/24-3/17/14, Staff
3 documented 38 bed checks on the observation
logs, but she only completed 17 bed checks
10

according to video footage. In addition, out of the
38 documented, only 3 checks were completed
at the same time or within a minute of the time
she wrote on the logs. Staff 3 documented all
checks between 10:30pm and 7:45am at 15-
minute increments exactly.
• LTAI Code of Ethics (3/2023) states employees shall
not falsify agency records, persons’ served records,
and/or other documents associated with their
employment with LTAI.
• Supervision Policy (rev. 3/6/24) states during sleeping
hours, employees should complete eyes on, variable
interval checks, not to exceed 15 minutes between
checks. Employees are responsible for documenting the
completion of their bedroom checks. Under no
circumstances should employees be asleep during their
shift.
• Staff 3’s employee file was reviewed. Staff 3 was
terminated on 10/17/22 for a reason unrelated to this
investigation. Staff 3 signed verification she
read/reviewed the facility’s Code of Ethics on 8/17/23.
• Staff 6 does not have any disciplinary actions in her
employee file. Staff 6 signed verification she
read/reviewed the Code of Ethics on 10/26/23.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per documentation and
video footage reviewed, Staff 3 and Staff 6 documented bed
checks which did not occur or bed checks occurred, but they did
not document the times of completion accurately.
Conclusion Violation Established
11

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
May 13, 2024
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 15, 2024
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
12

metadata.agency_name: Let's Talk About it Girl's Home III
